title: Medicare
content: medicare ¬∑ patient resource hub medicare what is medicare? the different parts of medicare who is eligible for medicare? how to enroll help with medicare costs have a trusted resource we missed? patient resource hub resource companion government benefits understand the different parts of medicare, what they cover, and how to enroll. medicare is the federal health insurance program for people who are 65 or older, certain younger people with disabilities, and people with end-stage renal disease (permanent kidney failure requiring dialysis or a transplant, sometimes called esrd). generally, you're eligible for medicare if you're a u.s. citizen or have been a legal resident for at least 5 years and: if you're already getting benefits from social security or the railroad retirement board (rrb), you'll automatically be enrolled in part a and part b starting the first day of the month you turn 65. if you're under 65 and disabled, you'll automatically get part a and part b after you get disability benefits from social security for 24 months. if you need to sign up, you can do so during your initial enrollment period, which usually starts 3 months before your 65th birthday and ends 3 months after. for more detailed information, visit the official medicare.gov website or call 1-800-medicare. if you have limited income and resources, you may qualify for help paying your medicare premiums and other costs. these programs include: you can learn more and apply through your state's medicaid office or the social security administration. submit it through the form so fellow patients can access the help, answers, and validation you‚Äôve already found. ¬© patient resource hub ¬∑ community-built support. medicare part a (hospital insurance): part a covers inpatient hospital stays, care in a skilled nursing facility, hospice care, and some home health care. medicare part b (medical insurance): part b covers certain doctors' services, outpatient care, medical supplies, and preventive services. medicare part c (medicare advantage): an ‚Äúall in one‚Äù alternative to original medicare. these bundled plans include part a, part b, and usually part d. most plans offer extra benefits that original medicare doesn‚Äôt cover ‚Äî like vision, hearing, and dental services. medicare part d (prescription drug coverage): part d adds prescription drug coverage to original medicare, some medicare cost plans, some medicare private-fee-for-service plans, and medicare medical savings account plans. you are age 65 or older. you are under 65 but have been entitled to social security disability insurance (ssdi) for 24 months. you have end-stage renal disease (esrd). you have amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (als), also known as lou gehrig's disease. medicare savings programs: state programs that help pay premiums, deductibles, and coinsurance. extra help: a program to help pay for medicare prescription drug coverage (part d) costs. government benefits

title: ABLE Accounts
mainHeading: Save for disability goals without losing essential benefits.
content: able accounts ¬∑ patient resource hub save for disability goals without losing essential benefits. learn more about able accounts: compare able program details for every state patient resource hub resource companion able accounts an able account is a tax-advantaged savings account that allows individuals with disabilities to build savings without affecting their eligibility for ssi, medicaid, and other means-tested programs (fafsa, hud, snap, etc.). investment income grows tax-free, and anyone can contribute‚Äîincluding friends, caregivers, and family. the first $100,000 in an able account do not count toward ssi‚Äôs resource limit. if your balance climbs higher, ssi payments pause, but medicaid continues; once the balance falls below $100,000, ssi restarts without a new application. deep dive expand each section to match the official patient resource hub notion guide on able rules‚Äîeligibility, contributions, spending rules, work considerations, and college planning. you are eligible to open an able account if: you cannot have more than one able account. not all states run able programs, and some offer extra perks like tax deductions or able-linked debit cards. compare current state programs to see what is available or accepting out-of-state applicants. you can open an account in any state program as long as you meet its eligibility criteria and the program is open to out-of-state enrollment. if your disability began before age 26, but ssa recorded an onset date after age 26 for ssi or ssdi, you can still pursue an able account with a physician certification confirming when your disability actually began and that it meets ssa‚Äôs definition of significant functional limitations. ssa staff are not responsible for determining able onset dates. congress is considering legislation to raise the age-of-onset cutoff to 46. support the able age adjustment act if it would help you or your community. 1 you do not have to be under age 26 today‚Äîyour disability simply needs to have started before your 26th birthday. 2 if you no longer meet disability criteria, your able account stays open until year-end. after that, new contributions stop and withdrawals count as non-qualified, which means they are taxable and may affect benefits. any person 1 can contribute to an able account, including friends, family, and community members. contributions must be made with post-tax dollars. they are not federally tax deductible, though some states offer deductions or credits for their programs. contribution limits most programs offer multiple investment portfolios and allow two changes per year to your investment mix. 1 the irs defines a ‚Äúperson‚Äù as an individual, trust, estate, partnership, association, company, or corporation‚Äînot just a single human. able funds must be used for qualified disability expenses (qdes). qdes cover essentials like education, food, housing, transportation, employment training and support, assistive technology, personal support services, healthcare costs, financial management, administrative services, and other expenses that improve health, independence, or quality of life. review the able national resource center qde guidance for more detail. some state programs offer debit cards for easier spending. otherwise you can transfer funds to a checking account, though a holding period may apply. once money leaves the able account and sits in a checking account, it can count toward asset limits‚Äîavoid keeping large transfers unspent for too long. able accounts increase allowable savings; they do not change how ssa treats earned income. wages continue to affect benefits the same way, even if you move that income into an able account. the able to work provision lets employed account holders exceed the $15,000 annual contribution limit. you can deposit an additional $12,760 1 (or your gross income for the year, whichever is lower). 1 the extra allowance is $15,950 in alaska and $14,680 in hawaii. the fafsa application excludes able balances from the assets it counts. you can roll over money from a 529 college savings plan into an able account without taxes or penalties as long as both accounts are held by you (or a qualified family member) and the rollover stays within the annual able contribution limit. state programs tap a state flag to see enrollment status, fees, contribution limits, and whether out-of-state residents can participate. data mirrors the patient resource hub notion database linked above. you have a disability with onset prior to your 26th birthday 1. you meet the severity of disability requirement by: receiving ssi or ssdi. having your doctor complete a disability certification affirming ‚Äúmarked and severe‚Äù functional limitations that are expected to last at least 12 months or result in death 2. receiving ssi or ssdi. having your doctor complete a disability certification affirming ‚Äúmarked and severe‚Äù functional limitations that are expected to last at least 12 months or result in death 2. combined deposits from all contributors (you, family, friends, etc.) are capped at $15,000 per tax year. lifetime caps depend on the state program and currently range from $235,000 to $589,000. able accounts deep dive state programs

medicine a note about intersectionality sources & further learning have a trusted resource we missed? patient resource hub resource companion social determinants of health not every community has the same access, safety, or trust inside the healthcare system. this guide pairs lived-experience explainers with action-oriented resources so you can quickly understand which forces are shaping care and how to advocate for something better. a guide to social determinants of health in a perfect world, ‚Äústandard of care‚Äù would mean that everyone gets evidence-based treatment, respectful communication, and the right follow-up. but the true standard shifts depending on income, disability, race, gender identity, immigration status, geography, and whether the system was built with you in mind. use this page to see how social determinants of health shape clinical decisions‚Äîand to find language you can bring into appointments, appeals, and community organizing. every topic links to the notion hub for a deeper dive, recommended readings, and ways to push for equitable standards. carceral health what access, consent, and continuity look like inside jails, prisons, and detention centers‚Äîand the policies that limit care. immigrant justice coverage rules, language access, and patient rights for people navigating the system without citizenship or stable documentation. economic stability how means testing, employer-based coverage, and out-of-pocket costs gate-keep diagnostics, medications, and preventive visits. geography rural hospital closures, urban deserts, transportation barriers, and how telehealth or mutual aid fills the gap. age equity why older adults are under-treated, how symptoms get dismissed as ‚Äújust aging,‚Äù and strategies for getting listened to. mental health provider shortages, waitlists, narrow insurance networks, and culturally unsafe care that keep people from treatment. racial justice historical harm, ongoing bias in diagnostics and pain management, and the community accountability efforts pushing systems to change. gender equity how research gaps, diagnostic stereotypes, and medical gaslighting impact women, femmes, and gender expansive patients. body autonomy anti-fat bias in exams, delayed diagnostics, and the harm of weight-centric treatment plans. each patient's experience is unique and usually shaped title: Disability Determination for Adults
content: disability determination for adults ¬∑ patient resource hub disability determination for adults disability determination for adults sequential evaluation for adults: share a missing disability benefit tip patient resource hub resource companion disability benefits follow ssa's five-step sequential evaluation to understand how adult disability decisions are made once basic ssi or ssdi criteria are met. if you appear to meet all other requirements for ssi or ssdi, your disability will be evaluated using the following questions: are you working? if you are performing substantial gainful activity (earning over $1,310/month‚Åç), you are not eligible for ssi. if you are not performing sga, ssa will send your case to the disability determination service (dds) for the next step. do you have a severe impairment? in order to be considered "severe", your condition must significantly limit your ability to do basic work-related activities (such as lifting, standing, walking, sitting, or remembering) for at least 12 months. if it does, your case will move on to the next step. does your impairment meet or medically equal a listing in ssa's "listing of impairments"? dds determines if your impairment(s) ‚Äúmeets‚Äù one of the listings by comparing it to the specific requirements in the listings. (it is not enough to have a diagnosis that is named in the listings, it must also match the severity.) if your impairment(s) meets or medically equals the requirements of a listing, and meets the 12-month duration requirement, you will be considered disabled and approved for benefits. if your impairment(s) is severe, but does not meet or medically equal a specific listing, dds determines the most you are physically and mentally able to do, despite the limitations resulting from your impairments using a "residual functional capacity" (rfc) assessment. depending on this result, your case will move on to the next step. are you able to do your past work? next, dds considers whether you are physically and mentally able to do any job that you did in the past according to your rfc. ssa does not consider whether you can get a particular job, but whether you can do a particular job. if you cannot do your past work, your claim moves on to the next step. can you do any other kind of work? finally, dds will consider your rfc limitations, vocational factors such as age, education and work experience, and work existing in the national economy. if you cannot perform other work that exists in significant numbers in the national economy, you will be considered disabled. ‚Åçthe monthly earnings limit for people who are blind is generally higher than the limit that applies to non-blind disabled workers. in 2021, the monthly earnings limit for people who are blind is $2,190. your real-life experience navigating ssa paperwork can help someone else feel less alone. submit your go-to explainer, video, or checklist. ¬© patient resource hub ¬∑ community-built support. are you working? content: disability determination for children ¬∑ patient resource hub disability determination for children disability determination for children is the child working? does the child have a severe impairment? share a missing disability benefit tip patient resource hub resource companion disability benefits see how ssa reviews work activity, medical listings, and functional limits when a child appears to meet the rest of the ssi or ssdi requirements. if a child appears to meet all other requirements for ssi or ssdi, their disability will be evaluated using the following questions: if a child is working and performing substantial gainful activity (earning over $1,310/month), ssa cannot consider the child disabled, and the sequential evaluation process ends here. if the child is not working, their case will be sent to the disability determination service (dds) for the next step. if the child is not performing sga, the disability determination service (dds) will determine if the child has a medically determinable physical or mental impairment (or combination of impairments) established by objective medical evidence and whether it is severe. an impairment(s) is not severe if it is only a slight abnormality or a combination of slight abnormalities that causes no more than minimal functional limitations. if the child has a severe medically determinable impairment(s), their case will move on to the next step. dds will determine if a child's impairment(s) "meets" one of the listings by comparing it to the specific requirements in the listings. (it is not enough to have a diagnosis that is named in the listings, it must also match the severity.) if the impairment(s) meets or medically equals the requirements of a listing, and meets the 12-month duration requirement, they will be considered disabled and approved for benefits. if their impairment(s) is severe, but does not meet or medically equal a specific listing, dds determines whether the impairment "functionally equals" the listings by evaluating the effects of the impairment(s) on the child's ability to function at home, at school, and in the community. dds considers how the child's functionings affect six domains: if a child's impairment(s) results in "marked" limitations in at least two of these domains of functioning, or an "extreme" limitation in at least one domain, then his or her impairment(s) functionally equals the listings. your real-life experience navigating ssa paperwork can help someone else feel less alone. submit your go-to explainer, video, or checklist. ¬© patient resource hub ¬∑ community-built support. acquiring & using information attending & completing tasks interacting with others moving about and manipulating objects caring for themselves health and physical wellbeing disability benefits

and how ssdi treats work activity. ssa considers any item you receive in cash or in kind that can be used to meet your need for food or shelter to be "income." generally, the more countable income you have, the less ssi benefits you will receive. if your countable income exceeds the allowable limit, you cannot receive ssi. to determine how your income affects your payment, ssa subtracts any income that does not count (see the list below) from your total income. the remaining amount is your "countable income," which is deducted from the ssi federal benefit rate to get your monthly ssi benefit. see example calculations from ssa. ssdi is only affected by your earned income. if you perform work that is over the substantial gainful activity (sga) limit, you are not eligible for benefits unless you are in a trial work period as part of the ssdi work incentives program. ssa excludes several income sources when figuring your payment, including: 1 in-kind support and maintenance is food, shelter, or both that somebody else provides for you. receiving this support can reduce your monthly ssi benefits by as much as $284.66 depending on the value of the help you receive. learn more and see example calculations from ssa here . 2 deemed income no longer applies if you do not live with your spouse or parent, when you turn 18 (if receiving child benefits), or when your alien sponsorship
